speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 14-1382, Americold Realty Trust v. ConAgra Foods. Mr. Pospisil.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why should we get to that question if, when this case began, even if you looked only to the citizenship of the trustees, there was no complete diversity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: At common law, the trustees could sue, couldn't they?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And these trustees could not sue, could -- can they?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Because of a new creature created by Maryland law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, this new entity is called a trust, but why is it more like a traditional trust than it is like another unincorporated, artificial entity, like an L.L.C.?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So who -- who owns -- who owns these assets under Maryland law? Is it the trustees, or is it this -- this new corporation-type entity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's the entity that can sue, and I assume that that's the entity that owns the property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and the trustees are sort of in the position of managers --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- just -- just as though you -- you hired a -- a CEO.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It can be owned by the entity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or --  or the trustees.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You mean in --  in one case, or you can have a different type of trust?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: In one case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That was a trustee who had Alderson Reporting Company the authority to sue, right, in the trustee's own name?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that's not the case here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But didn't -- didn't -- Carden treated Navarro as a case where the suit was against the individual members, the individual trustees, trustees as individuals, not the trust.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So I thought Carden was trying -- was set up -- if you're a corporation, that's one thing. If you're any other kind of association, we look to the members, the shareholders. I mean the -- the limited partners as well as the partners. Just Alderson Reporting Company drawing a clear line between corporations on one side, all other associations, and -- with the -- with the added notion that, if Congress wants to make it different, Congress can do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, this is not a traditional trust, because this is shareholders and not beneficiaries.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It --  it's a very different sort of concept. So now you're asking us to come and place trustee law above our general rule, that you're either a corporation or you're not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And only the corporation can have a place of business or an --  a place of incorporation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I thought the shareholders owned the property. They had the legal interest in the law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that the distinction in Carden was quite plain, that Carden was a case against the individual trustees, not against the trust. Carden did say that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: On the ground that the suit there was against the individual trustees, not the trust.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I thought that one of the virtues of Carden was that it just set up very categorical, bright-line rule. Everything that's an artificial legal entity that's not a corporation ought to be treated in the same way. Doesn't matter what you call yourself; you can put trust in the title, or not Alderson Reporting Company put trust in the title. If you're an artificial legal entity that is not a corporation, that's subject to the rule of Carden. And there's something, too, just doing that in that bright-line, categorical way, so that we don't have to look at the thousands of different variations among legal entities and decide which fits in which box.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why should it matter as long as it's not a corporation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How many are there in this one?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that --  you know, how -- how many are --  are there normally in these special Maryland trusts?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: At least a hundred.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you know of any that -- that are more than a thousand?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Really?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, why should -- I mean, it -- it is the person who's invoking diversity jurisdiction has to show the diversity, and if they can't, then you sue in State court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But that's true of partnerships; it's true of LLCs; it's true of a wide variety of legal entities.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Does it -- is it a pertinent consideration in terms of the impact on Federal jurisdiction? I mean, this is standard, run-of-the-mill commercial dispute about a commercial accident. And adopting one position would limit the number of times that such disputes would be brought in Federal court. The other one will expand it. Is that -- I mean, does Americold really feel that it's not going to get a fair shake in the Kansas courts in this case? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, maybe that's a problem for -- for Congress as -- as the problem of corporations was. You know, Congress adopted a special rule for corporations, and maybe it ought to adopt a special rule for real estate investment trusts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you have any definition of what the common law trust was? I'll -- I'll give you the ones I understand, and you tell me how you don't. Alderson Reporting Company I thought in a common law trust, the trustees had legal title. They owned the assets. They could be sued individually, and --  and they could sue in their own names. In this REIT, as I understand it, the assets are in the name of the Trust, not in the name of the individual trustees, and it is the Trust that sues or can be sued, not the individual trustees. Am I wrong about those --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  so go --  I'm right on the first part.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you have a section for that? I'm going to look it up, so.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Because that's not how I originally understood things, but --  that's all right --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  you can give it to me on rebuttal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Thank you.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Duggan.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Would you describe beneficiaries as a member --  member of a trust? I mean, as you articulate it. I think what's different than this, and Carden sort of gets you past the trust. But you then have to still make a choice: Okay. We're not going to look at the trust. Do we look at the trustees or the beneficiaries? And I --  I don't know if I'd call beneficiaries members of a trust.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And in this case you couldn't sue the trustees individually, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Duggan, do you think it's possible that we took a bit of a wrong turn in -- in Carden? In other words, that, in fact, all of these entities should be treated like corporations and that the strongest arguments on the other side, you know, are really those arguments. And those arguments fly in the face of Carden but that -- but they're really arguments about why -- why not treat these just like a corporation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If we -- if we made the law in the first place, why should we say, well, we made it, but we're not going to fix it? Let Congress fix it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The problem, just from the point of view of the common sense of it, is you have an organization that has, A, the organization; B, the trustees; and C, the shareholders. Alderson Reporting Company So applying Carden, what you would say -- and Navarro: If you sue the trustees, you look to their citizenship. But if you sue the trust itself, you don't look to the citizenship of the trust; you don't look to the citizenship of the trustees. You go beyond that and look to the citizenship of the members. I mean, that seems odd. Why do you look to the members or the shareholders, or the -- or the beneficiaries where you sue the trust itself but you don't in the identical situation where the law of the State allows you to sue the trustees? I mean, that seems such a sport, such a -- a fluke.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is it the Petitioner's position that the Real Estate Investment Trust is more like a trust than an LLC, than a limited partnership? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And -- and if that is their position, what would your response be?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why -- why is an REIT more like a limited partner than it is a common law trust?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, it seems to me that's a wash because what you describe is a common law trust as well, so I'm --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That sounds like a wash.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What -- a common law trust exists in nature? That's the common law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But it's not an artificial entity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Because we know it and love it so well or what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Look -- look at the other odd thing in writing this opinion your way. You say, Alderson Reporting Company well, this isn't really like a trust. I mean, it is sort of a trust, but there are important differences. They can sue and be sued. The trust itself can hold the property, and the beneficiaries do not have an equitable interest. And because they don't have an equitable interest, it's more like a private association or, et cetera, in Carden. But, of course, that means that we look to their interest. We look to their property. We're basically having them as part of the necessary parties because they have a property interest, the very people we just said that this is a different kind of organization because they lack an equitable interest in the property.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I just have one question on the Safeway and Kraft business. In the Tenth Circuit, you can -- you advised the court that you thought they were dispensable, nondiverse parties, but they hadn't appealed. And before this Court, you agreed to dismiss another dispensable, nondiverse party. And then your brief comes in and you say, well, I've changed my mind. They're not dispensable. It -- I wonder why. It seems a bit of sharp practice.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So just extend the litigation even further than it's --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay. Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Pospisil, you have eleven minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: His point really is that this is sort of like a trust but not very much. And indeed, the key point, to me, is that the shareholders here have no beneficial interest in the property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And then you say in the section shareholders shall have no interest in the property of the trust.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't know. I didn't write -- I didn't write Section 6; your client did. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's what it says, so how are we supposed to take that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I --  I don't --  who -- who --  who was the party? Who was the defendant in that case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You say the trustees were not a party?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You separate the board of trustees from the -- from the trustees?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is -- is that standard with -- with common law trusts? Can you sue either the trustees or the board of trustees?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When you have a bunch of trustees, aren't they normally referred to as the board of trustees?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There's a special statute that --  that allowed the board of trustees --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes. I do have one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Suppose I wanted a list. Alderson Reporting Company I --  I wanted a list, a synthesis of which Bogert or -- or Scott on trusts has as the characteristic of the traditional common law trusts. And then I'd like, over in the other column, the characteristics of your organization.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And now what do I read? I --  I don't think you can list them now. Is there something I can read just to get an idea of that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Maybe they are identical. Are you going to say they're --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
